During project implementation, one team finds out that a key project deliverable was not budgeted.
What should the project manager do first?

choices.B: Hold the team accountable and ask for an immediate solution.
choices.D: Remove the deliverable from the project scope.
choices.C: Meet with the team to discuss alternatives.
choices.A: Escalate the issue to the project sponsor for resolution.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
The first thing the project manager should do in this situation is to hold a meeting with the team to discuss alternatives (Option C). The team should come together to brainstorm ideas on how to solve the problem while balancing the budget. 

It is important to involve the team in finding a solution because they are the ones who are most familiar with the project and can provide valuable insights. This also gives the team a sense of ownership of the project and increases their commitment to finding a solution.

If the team is unable to identify a viable alternative, the project manager can then escalate the issue to the project sponsor for resolution (Option A). Removing the deliverable from the project scope (Option D) or holding the team accountable and asking for an immediate solution (Option B) should not be the first course of action as they do not involve finding a solution that supports the project objectives.

During the final stage of the launch for a new design, team members are having a conflict about some features of the design.
What should the project manager do?

discussion.content:

When some team members are struggling to deliver certain features, it is essential to identify the root cause of the issue and work with the team to find a solution. In this case, the team members are struggling to deliver certain features because they have never worked on this type of solution. Encouraging the team to hold a knowledge-sharing session in each iteration can help team members share their expertise, learn from each other, and address any knowledge gaps that may exist.
